questions.text: Causes of postdatism include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Previous caesarean section is not a causative factor for postdatism. In contrast, postdated pregnancy is primarily associated with maternal, fetal, placental, or constitutional causes that delay the onset of labour.

Definition and Aetiology of Postdated Pregnancy:

  • Postdated (postterm) pregnancy is defined as gestation that extends to ≥42 completed weeks (≥294 days) from the first day of the last menstrual period.
  • This condition is linked with increased perinatal risks such as stillbirth, meconium aspiration, macrosomia, and oligohydramnios.

Causes of Postdatism:

questions.text: All of the following are fetal complications of prolonged pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fetal ascites is not a known complication of post-term pregnancy. In contrast, prolonged pregnancy is associated with various complications due to placental senescence and oligohydramnios, which increase the risk of fetal distress, meconium aspiration, and even congenital anomalies like anencephaly.

  • Definition: Post-term pregnancy is defined as a pregnancy that extends to or beyond 42 weeks (294 days) from the first day of the last menstrual period.
  • Etiologies of Postdatism:
    • Incorrect dating: The most common cause is due to inaccurate LMP recall.
    • Hereditary tendency: Familial predisposition seen across generations.
    • Maternal factors: Nulliparity, elderly multipara, sedentary lifestyle.
    • Fetal factors: Congenital anomalies like anencephaly result in impaired fetal HPA axis and diminished cortisol production, delaying labour onset.
    • Placental causes: Sulfatase deficiency leads to low estrogen levels.
  • Fetal Complications of Prolonged Pregnancy:

Explanation of Other Options:

Fetal distress (Option B): Common in post-term pregnancy due to placental insufficiency and meconium-stained liquor.

Oligohydramnios (Option C): A hallmark complication due to reduced fetal urine production.

Anencephaly (Option D): A fetal anomaly causing failure of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, leading to postdatism.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for the induction of labour?
questions.solution:
Post-term pregnancy (≥42 weeks of gestation) is a well-established indication for induction of labour to avoid increased perinatal morbidity and mortality.

  • Beyond 42 weeks, risks such as oligohydramnios, macrosomia, meconium aspiration, and stillbirth rise significantly.
  • Induction at this point improves outcomes without a significant increase in cesarean delivery rates.

Explanation of Other Options:

Active genital herpes (Option A): Not an indication for induction. Cesarean delivery is the preferred mode due to the risk of neonatal herpes transmission during vaginal birth. Induction is contraindicated in this case.

Polyhydramnios (Option B): Not an absolute indication. May be considered for induction only if there are maternal symptoms (e.g., respiratory difficulty), malpresentation, or risk of cord prolapse. Otherwise, managed expectantly.

choices.text: Induction of labour at 42 weeks with liquor monitoring
Induction of labour after assessment of the pelvis

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravida patient presents to the antenatal clinic at 41 weeks of pregnancy. She denies abdominal pain. Her vitals are stable: temperature 98°F, BP 150/100 mmHg, and pulse 84 bpm. TAS reveals an adequate amount of liquor. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At 41 weeks of gestation in a stable primigravida with adequate liquor, the appropriate next step is the assessment of the cervix/pelvis, followed by labour induction, as per the management algorithm for post-term pregnancy.


Explanation of Other Options:

Induction at 42 weeks with liquor monitoring (Option A): Waiting until 42 weeks is not advised when already at 41 weeks with stable parameters. ACOG and Williams recommend fetal surveillance or induction by 41 weeks.

Caesarean at 42 weeks (Option C): Elective cesarean is not indicated solely for post-date pregnancy without other complications (e.g., unfavourable cervix, fetal distress).

Immediate caesarean section (Option D): Not warranted; there's no evidence of labour, fetal distress, or obstetric emergency.

questions.text: Causes of intrauterine fetal death include:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the listed factors- diabetes, multifetal pregnancy, and advanced maternal age—are associated with an increased risk of intrauterine fetal death.

(Other options are ruled out)

choices.text: 2 days of intrauterine fetal death
7 days of intrauterine fetal death
2 weeks of intrauterine fetal death
4 weeks of intrauterine fetal death

questions.text: The Spalding sign is seen after:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Spalding sign typically appears around 7 days after fetal demise, due to the overlapping of cranial bones secondary to brain tissue liquefaction and ligamentous weakening.

  • Definition of Spalding sign:
    • Seen in intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD).
    • Describes the irregular overlapping of the fetal skull bones on imaging.
    • Caused by liquefaction of brain tissue and softening of cranial ligaments.
    • Best detected on X-ray or ultrasonography.
  • Radiological features in IUFD:
  • Other associated findings:
    • Absence of fetal movements and heart sounds.
    • Regression of fundal height and uterine size.
    • Eggshell skull or collapsed fetal head on ultrasound.

Explanation of Other Options:

2 days of intrauterine fetal death (Option A): Too early; no liquefaction or overlap yet.

2 weeks of intrauterine fetal death (Option C): Some signs persist, but Spalding is typically present by 7 days.

4 weeks of intrauterine fetal death (Option D): May show advanced decomposition or even calcification; Spalding appears earlier.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific maternal complication that may occur in intrauterine fetal death (IUFD)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among maternal complications following IUFD, DIC is the most specific and serious. It occurs due to the gradual absorption of thromboplastin from the dead fetus and placenta into the maternal circulation.

  • Complications of IUFD:
  • DIC is especially noted as a specific haematological complication, distinguishing it from the more general or secondary risks like infection or thrombophlebitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Infection (Option A): This may occur post-membrane rupture, but is less specific than DIC.

Amniotic fluid embolism (Option C): Rare, unrelated to IUFD retention.

Thrombophlebitis (Option D): Possible but non-specific and much less frequent.

questions.text: Indication of caesarean section in case of intrauterine fetal death includes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Caesarean section is rarely indicated in intrauterine fetal death (IUFD). The few absolute indications include central placenta previa, transverse lie, or previous two or more cesarean sections.

Placental abruption is not a routine indication for LSCS in IUFD unless other obstetric indications are present (e.g., coagulopathy, failure of progress).

  • Indications for Caesarean in IUFD:

Explanation of Other Options:

Previous one caesarean section (Option A): Not an indication for CS; vaginal delivery is usually safe.

Placental abruption (Option C): Not by itself an indication; managed conservatively if maternal condition permits.

Explanation:

The most specific ultrasound signs of intrauterine fetal demise include the absence of fetal cardiac activity and overlapping of cranial bones (Spalding sign). These radiological signs provide confirmatory evidence of fetal death.

  • Intrauterine fetal death is the death of the fetus in utero after the period of viability (after 22 weeks) or when the fetus weighs more than 500 g.

IUD can be diagnosed clinically by:

  • The size of the uterus is less than the period of gestation.
  • Liquor decreased.
  • FHS absent.
  • Fetal movements are absent.

Radiological signs of IUD

  • Roberts' sign:Presence of gas in the fetal large vessels(earliest sign seen 12 hours after fetal death).
  • Ball sign:Crumpled up the spine of the fetus or hyperflexion of the spine
  • Spalding's sign:Overlapping of fetal skull bones seen due to shrinkage of cerebrum after the death of the fetus
  • Absence of fetal cardiac activity on ultrasound scan (diagnostic)

Explanation of Other Options:

'Halo' sign of head (Option A): Not a specific sign of IUFD; not used in fetal death diagnosis.

Heartbeat absent (Option B): One of the most reliable signs of IUFD.

Spalding sign (Option C): Characteristic radiological sign; overlapping of skull bones due to cerebral tissue liquefaction.

questions.text: A patient at 24 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD), which occurred at 17 weeks but did not result in spontaneous expulsion. This patient is at increased risk for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is Consumptive coagulopathy with hypofibrinogenemia, which is a recognised maternal complication when a dead fetus is retained in utero for more than 4–5 weeks.

  • Dead fetal tissue can release thromboplastin that activates coagulation pathways, leading to the gradual development of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • This phenomenon is also referred to as consumptive coagulopathy and is more commonly seen in concealed placental abruption or a retained dead fetus.
  • Clinically, this manifests with low fibrinogen levels and prolonged PT/aPTT.
  • Monitoring of the coagulation profile is critical in such cases.

Explanation of Other Options:

Septic abortion (Option A): More commonly associated with instrumentation or infection, not prolonged fetal retention.

Recurrent abortion (Option B): Refers to ≥3 consecutive pregnancy losses; not directly related to this scenario.

Future infertility (Option D): Not a direct consequence of IUFD with fetal retention unless complicated by infection or uterine injury.
